algorithm: {The new algorithm combines objective-aware selection with a multi-objective edge swap operator that dynamically prioritizes objectives based on their relative improvement potential and applies a sequence of edge swaps to explore diverse neighborhoods while maintaining feasibility.}
function:
def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    if not archive:
        raise ValueError("Archive is empty")

    # Select a solution with high potential for improvement (e.g., not too similar to others)
    selected_idx = np.random.choice(len(archive))
    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()
    n = len(new_solution)

    # Calculate objective improvement potential
    obj1, obj2, obj3 = archive[selected_idx][1]
    total_obj = obj1 + obj2 + obj3
    obj_weights = (obj1/total_obj, obj2/total_obj, obj3/total_obj)

    # Perform multi-objective edge swaps
    for _ in range(2):  # Number of swaps to perform
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))

        # Calculate potential improvement for each objective
        improvements = [
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]])
        ]

        # Weighted improvement score
        weighted_improvement = sum(w * imp for w, imp in zip(obj_weights, improvements))

        if weighted_improvement < 0:  # Only accept if at least one objective improves
            # Perform the edge swap
            new_solution[i], new_solution[j] = new_solution[j], new_solution[i]

    return new_solution

def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    if len(archive) > 1:
        # Calculate the range of each objective across the archive
        obj1 = [obj[0] for _, obj in archive]
        obj2 = [obj[1] for _, obj in archive]
        obj3 = [obj[2] for _, obj in archive]

        max_range = max(max(obj1) - min(obj1), max(obj2) - min(obj2), max(obj3) - min(obj3))

        # Select the solution with the highest objective value in the dimension with the largest range
        if max_range == max(obj1) - min(obj1):
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj1)
        elif max_range == max(obj2) - min(obj2):
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj2)
        else:
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj3)
    else:
        selected_idx = 0

    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()

    # Apply a hybrid local search operator: 2-opt with objective-aware edge selection
    n = len(new_solution)
    for _ in range(10):  # Limit the number of attempts to avoid excessive computation
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))
        if i == 0 and j == n - 1:
            continue  # Avoid swapping the start and end nodes

        # Calculate the change in all three objectives
        delta_obj1 = (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj2 = (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj3 = (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        # Accept the move if it improves at least one objective
        if delta_obj1 < 0 or delta_obj2 < 0 or delta_obj3 < 0:
            new_solution[i:j+1] = new_solution[i:j+1][::-1]
            break

    return new_solution

def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    if len(archive) > 1:
        # Calculate the range of each objective across the archive
        obj1 = [obj[0] for _, obj in archive]
        obj2 = [obj[1] for _, obj in archive]
        obj3 = [obj[2] for _, obj in archive]

        max_range = max(max(obj1) - min(obj1), max(obj2) - min(obj2), max(obj3) - min(obj3))

        # Select the solution with the highest objective value in the dimension with the largest range
        if max_range == max(obj1) - min(obj1):
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj1)
        elif max_range == max(obj2) - min(obj2):
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj2)
        else:
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj3)
    else:
        selected_idx = 0

    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()

    # Apply a hybrid local search operator: 2-opt with objective-aware edge selection
    n = len(new_solution)
    for _ in range(10):  # Limit the number of attempts to avoid excessive computation
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))
        if i == 0 and j == n - 1:
            continue  # Avoid swapping the start and end nodes

        # Calculate the change in all three objectives
        delta_obj1 = (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj2 = (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj3 = (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        # Accept the move if it improves at least one objective
        if delta_obj1 < 0 or delta_obj2 < 0 or delta_obj3 < 0:
            new_solution[i:j+1] = new_solution[i:j+1][::-1]
            break

    return new_solution

algorithm: {The new algorithm combines objective-aware selection with a multi-objective edge swap operator that dynamically prioritizes objectives based on their relative improvement potential and applies a sequence of edge swaps to explore diverse neighborhoods while maintaining feasibility.}
function:
def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    if not archive:
        raise ValueError("Archive is empty")

    # Select a solution with high potential for improvement (e.g., not too similar to others)
    selected_idx = np.random.choice(len(archive))
    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()
    n = len(new_solution)

    # Calculate objective improvement potential
    obj1, obj2, obj3 = archive[selected_idx][1]
    total_obj = obj1 + obj2 + obj3
    obj_weights = (obj1/total_obj, obj2/total_obj, obj3/total_obj)

    # Perform multi-objective edge swaps
    for _ in range(2):  # Number of swaps to perform
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))

        # Calculate potential improvement for each objective
        improvements = [
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]])
        ]

        # Weighted improvement score
        weighted_improvement = sum(w * imp for w, imp in zip(obj_weights, improvements))

        if weighted_improvement < 0:  # Only accept if at least one objective improves
            # Perform the edge swap
            new_solution[i], new_solution[j] = new_solution[j], new_solution[i]

    return new_solution

algorithm: {This new algorithm employs a dynamic objective prioritization approach with adaptive neighborhood exploration, using a novel weighted improvement score that combines both absolute and relative improvements across all objectives, followed by a sequence of multi-edge swaps to create diverse high-quality neighbors while maintaining feasibility.}
function:
def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """
    Select a promising solution from the archive and generate a neighbor solution from it.

    Args:
    archive: List of (solution, objective) pairs. Each solution is a numpy array of node IDs.
             Each objective is a tuple of three float values.
    instance: Numpy array of shape (N, 4). Each row corresponds to a node and contains its coordinates in two 2D spaces: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
    distance_matrix_1: Distance matrix in the first objective space.
    distance_matrix_2: Distance matrix in the second objective space.
    distance_matrix_3: Distance matrix in the third objective space.

    Returns:
    A new neighbor solution (numpy array).
    """
    if not archive:
        raise ValueError("Archive is empty")

    # Select solution with highest potential for improvement
    selected_idx = np.random.choice(len(archive))
    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()
    n = len(new_solution)

    # Calculate objective improvement potential
    obj1, obj2, obj3 = archive[selected_idx][1]
    total_obj = obj1 + obj2 + obj3
    obj_weights = (obj1/total_obj, obj2/total_obj, obj3/total_obj)

    # Perform multi-objective edge swaps
    for _ in range(3):  # Increased number of swaps
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))

        # Calculate potential improvement for each objective
        improvements = [
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]])
        ]

        # Weighted improvement score with additional relative improvement factor
        weighted_improvement = sum(w * imp for w, imp in zip(obj_weights, improvements))
        relative_improvement = sum((imp / (obj1 + obj2 + obj3)) for imp in improvements)

        combined_score = 0.7 * weighted_improvement + 0.3 * relative_improvement

        if combined_score < 0:  # Only accept if combined score shows improvement
            # Perform the edge swap
            new_solution[i], new_solution[j] = new_solution[j], new_solution[i]

    return new_solution

algorithm: {The new algorithm selects a solution from the archive based on its diversity and applies a multi-objective crossover operator that combines segments from different solutions while ensuring feasibility, then performs a sequence of objective-aware edge insertions to further improve the solution.}
function:
def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """
    Select a promising solution from the archive and generate a neighbor solution from it.

    Args:
    archive: List of (solution, objective) pairs. Each solution is a numpy array of node IDs.
             Each objective is a tuple of three float values.
    instance: Numpy array of shape (N, 4). Each row corresponds to a node and contains its coordinates in two 2D spaces: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
    distance_matrix_1: Distance matrix in the first objective space.
    distance_matrix_2: Distance matrix in the second objective space.
    distance_matrix_3: Distance matrix in the third objective space.

    Returns:
    A new neighbor solution (numpy array).
    """
    if not archive:
        raise ValueError("Archive is empty")

    # Select a diverse solution (not too similar to others)
    selected_idx = np.random.choice(len(archive))
    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()

    # Apply multi-objective crossover with another random solution
    if len(archive) > 1:
        other_idx = np.random.choice([i for i in range(len(archive)) if i != selected_idx])
        other_solution = archive[other_idx][0]

        # Determine crossover points
        n = len(new_solution)
        start, end = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))

        # Create a new solution by combining segments from both solutions
        new_solution = np.concatenate([
            new_solution[:start],
            other_solution[start:end],
            new_solution[end:]
        ])

        # Remove duplicates and fill missing nodes
        missing_nodes = set(base_solution) - set(new_solution)
        for node in missing_nodes:
            pos = np.random.randint(0, n)
            new_solution = np.insert(new_solution, pos, node)

        # Ensure feasibility by removing extra nodes
        if len(new_solution) > n:
            new_solution = new_solution[:n]

    # Perform objective-aware edge insertions
    n = len(new_solution)
    for _ in range(3):  # Number of insertions to perform
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))

        # Calculate potential improvement for each objective
        improvements = [
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]]),
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]]) -
            (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] + distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j-1], new_solution[j]])
        ]

        # Accept if at least one objective improves
        if any(imp < 0 for imp in improvements):
            # Perform the edge insertion
            node = new_solution[j]
            new_solution = np.delete(new_solution, j)
            new_solution = np.insert(new_solution, i, node)

    return new_solution

def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    if len(archive) > 1:
        # Calculate the range of each objective across the archive
        obj1 = [obj[0] for _, obj in archive]
        obj2 = [obj[1] for _, obj in archive]
        obj3 = [obj[2] for _, obj in archive]

        max_range = max(max(obj1) - min(obj1), max(obj2) - min(obj2), max(obj3) - min(obj3))

        # Select the solution with the highest objective value in the dimension with the largest range
        if max_range == max(obj1) - min(obj1):
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj1)
        elif max_range == max(obj2) - min(obj2):
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj2)
        else:
            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj3)
    else:
        selected_idx = 0

    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()

    # Apply a hybrid local search operator: 2-opt with objective-aware edge selection
    n = len(new_solution)
    for _ in range(10):  # Limit the number of attempts to avoid excessive computation
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))
        if i == 0 and j == n - 1:
            continue  # Avoid swapping the start and end nodes

        # Calculate the change in all three objectives
        delta_obj1 = (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj2 = (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj3 = (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        # Accept the move if it improves at least one objective
        if delta_obj1 < 0 or delta_obj2 < 0 or delta_obj3 < 0:
            new_solution[i:j+1] = new_solution[i:j+1][::-1]
            break

    return new_solution

def select_neighbor(archive: List[Tuple[np.ndarray, Tuple[float, float]]], instance: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_1: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_2: np.ndarray, distance_matrix_3: np.ndarray) -> np.ndarray:
    """
    Select a promising solution from the archive and generate a neighbor solution from it.

    Args:
    archive: List of (solution, objective) pairs. Each solution is a numpy array of node IDs.
             Each objective is a tuple of three float values.
    instance: Numpy array of shape (N, 4). Each row corresponds to a node and contains its coordinates in two 2D spaces: (x1, y1, x2, y2).
    distance_matrix_1: Distance matrix in the first objective space.
    distance_matrix_2: Distance matrix in the second objective space.
    distance_matrix_3: Distance matrix in the third objective space.

    Returns:
    A new neighbor solution (numpy array).
    """
    if not archive:
        raise ValueError("Archive is empty")

    # Normalize objectives and select the solution with highest sum of normalized values
    obj_values = np.array([obj for _, obj in archive])
    normalized_obj = (obj_values - obj_values.min(axis=0)) / (obj_values.max(axis=0) - obj_values.min(axis=0) + 1e-8)
    selected_idx = np.argmax(normalized_obj.sum(axis=1))
    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()

    # Multi-objective edge swap operator
    n = len(new_solution)
    for _ in range(5):  # Limit iterations
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))
        if i == 0 and j == n-1:
            continue  # Avoid start-end swap

        # Calculate change in all objectives
        delta_obj1 = (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                     distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                     distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                     distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj2 = (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                     distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                     distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                     distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj3 = (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                     distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                     distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                     distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        # Accept if at least one objective improves
        if delta_obj1 < 0 or delta_obj2 < 0 or delta_obj3 < 0:
            new_solution[i:j+1] = new_solution[i:j+1][::-1]
            break

    return new_solution

        raise ValueError("Archive is empty")

    n = len(new_solution)

    obj1, obj2, obj3 = archive[selected_idx][1]
    total_obj = obj1 + obj2 + obj3

            # Perform the edge swap
            new_solution[i], new_solution[j] = new_solution[j], new_solution[i]

    return new_solution

    if len(archive) > 1:
        # Calculate the range of each objective across the archive
        obj1 = [obj[0] for _, obj in archive]
        obj2 = [obj[1] for _, obj in archive]
        obj3 = [obj[2] for _, obj in archive]

        max_range = max(max(obj1) - min(obj1), max(obj2) - min(obj2), max(obj3) - min(obj3))

        if max_range == max(obj1) - min(obj1):

            selected_idx = np.argmax(obj2)

    else:
        selected_idx = 0

    base_solution = archive[selected_idx][0].copy()
    new_solution = base_solution.copy()

    # Apply a hybrid local search operator: 2-opt with objective-aware edge selection
    n = len(new_solution)
    for _ in range(10):  # Limit the number of attempts to avoid excessive computation
        i, j = sorted(np.random.choice(n, 2, replace=False))
        if i == 0 and j == n - 1:
            continue  # Avoid swapping the start and end nodes

        # Calculate the change in all three objectives
        delta_obj1 = (distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_1[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj2 = (distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_2[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        delta_obj3 = (distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[j]] +
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(i+1)%n]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[i-1], new_solution[i]] -
                      distance_matrix_3[new_solution[j], new_solution[(j+1)%n]])

        # Accept the move if it improves at least one objective
        if delta_obj1 < 0 or delta_obj2 < 0 or delta_obj3 < 0:
            new_solution[i:j+1] = new_solution[i:j+1][::-1]
            break

    return new_solution
